text.text_translated:
Most kinds of spiders have **venom**, which is a poisonous liquid. Its purpose is to stun or kill the animals they hunt, and not to attack people. In fact, only 25 known kinds of spiders produce venom that can really harm humans. Although their bites can be painful, they are not often deadly. For example, Australia's Sydney funnel-web spider, which is famous because it is dangerous, has not killed anyone since an anti-venom was developed in 1981.

However, you should be careful not to make hairy spiders, like tarantulas, angry. When they feel they are in danger, they protect themselves by sending out a cloud of **urticating hairs**, which are irritating hairs. These hairs then stick into the skin or eyes of the attacker.
